titleproper.value:
Guide to the Henry Nagel papers
                    <num>2015.004</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Melissa Aaronberg

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2016-12-19T11:06-0500</date>

extent.value: in one manuscript box and one oversize folder

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: These papers are comprised of items belonging to Henry Nagel, a resident of Brooklyn, New York, who was employed as Controller for Chase National Bank. These papers include Henry Nagel's personal documents and business correspondence. These papers also include items related to New York University, Packer Collegiate Institute, the United States Treasury War Finance Commission, and the New York Veteran Police Association. An avid basketball fan, Henry Nagel's papers include newspaper clippings related to the Crescent basketball team of St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Henry Nagel papers, 2015.004, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

Henry Nagel (1883-1964) was a bank controller and life-long Brooklyn, New York, resident. He had a long and successful career at Chase Bank and its predecessor institutions. He married Caroline Newell on October 7, 1908. Their only child, Winifred Gladys Nagel Pitt, was born on July 5, 1912. His banking career began in 1904 after his graduation from Boy's High School, in the Bedfordâ€“Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn. In the mid-1920s, he briefly worked at Chase Bank's Paris branch. He was also a basketball player in his youth, and avidly followed the Crescent basketball team at his church, St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

The papers also include items relating to Henry Nagel's daughter, Winifred Gladys Nagel Pitt. These primarily relate to her marriage to Frank R. Pitt in 1937. They also include several items relating to Packer Collegiate Institute, where she attended school, including: 
                <emph render="italic">Supplementary Reading for the Academic and Collegiate Schools</emph> booklet (1922), Class Day program (1931), the Annual Sermon to the Graduating Class (1931), clippings, photographs, and an address titled "Bender of the Twig" by school President Paul D. Schafer (1939).
